trans-unit.source: Redirecting Data with Out Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Redirecting Data with Out Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Redirecting Data with Out-* Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Redirecting Data with Out-* Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell provides several cmdlets that let you control data output directly.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell provides several cmdlets that let you control data output directly.

trans-unit.source: These cmdlets share two important characteristics.
trans-unit.target: These cmdlets share two important characteristics.

trans-unit.source: First, they generally transform data to some form of text.
trans-unit.target: First, they generally transform data to some form of text.

trans-unit.source: They do this because they output the data to system components that require text input.
trans-unit.target: They do this because they output the data to system components that require text input.

trans-unit.source: This means they need to represent the objects as text.
trans-unit.target: This means they need to represent the objects as text.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, the text is formatted as you see it in the Windows PowerShell console window.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, the text is formatted as you see it in the Windows PowerShell console window.

trans-unit.source: Second, these cmdlets use the Windows PowerShell verb **Out** because they send information out from Windows PowerShell to somewhere else.
trans-unit.target: Second, these cmdlets use the Windows PowerShell verb **Out** because they send information out from Windows PowerShell to somewhere else.

trans-unit.source: The **Out-Host** cmdlet is no exception: the host window display is outside of Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-Host** cmdlet is no exception: the host window display is outside of Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: This is important because when data is sent out of Windows PowerShell, it is actually removed.
trans-unit.target: This is important because when data is sent out of Windows PowerShell, it is actually removed.

trans-unit.source: You can see this if you try to create a pipeline that pages data to the host window, and then attempt to format it as a list, as shown here:
trans-unit.target: You can see this if you try to create a pipeline that pages data to the host window, and then attempt to format it as a list, as shown here:

trans-unit.source: You might expect the command to display pages of process information in list format.
trans-unit.target: You might expect the command to display pages of process information in list format.

trans-unit.source: Instead, it displays the default tabular list:
trans-unit.target: Instead, it displays the default tabular list:

trans-unit.source: The **Out-Host** cmdlet sends the data directly to the console, so the **Format-List** command never receives anything to format.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-Host** cmdlet sends the data directly to the console, so the **Format-List** command never receives anything to format.

trans-unit.source: The correct way to structure this command is to put the **Out-Host** cmdlet at the end of the pipeline as shown below.
trans-unit.target: The correct way to structure this command is to put the **Out-Host** cmdlet at the end of the pipeline as shown below.

trans-unit.source: This causes the process data to be formatted in a list before being paged and displayed.
trans-unit.target: This causes the process data to be formatted in a list before being paged and displayed.

trans-unit.source: This applies to all of the **Out** cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This applies to all of the **Out** cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: An **Out** cmdlet should always appear at the end of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: An **Out** cmdlet should always appear at the end of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: All the **Out** cmdlets render output as text, using the formatting in effect for the console window, including line length limits.
trans-unit.target: All the **Out** cmdlets render output as text, using the formatting in effect for the console window, including line length limits.

trans-unit.source: Paging Console Output (Out-Host)
trans-unit.target: Paging Console Output (Out-Host)

trans-unit.source: By default, Windows PowerShell sends data to the host window, which is exactly what the Out-Host cmdlet does.
trans-unit.target: By default, Windows PowerShell sends data to the host window, which is exactly what the Out-Host cmdlet does.

trans-unit.source: The primary use for the Out-Host cmdlet is paging data as we discussed earlier.
trans-unit.target: The primary use for the Out-Host cmdlet is paging data as we discussed earlier.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command uses Out-Host to page the output of the Get-Command cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command uses Out-Host to page the output of the Get-Command cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: You can also use the **more** function to page data.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the **more** function to page data.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell, **more** is a function that calls **Out-Host -Paging**.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell, **more** is a function that calls **Out-Host -Paging**.

trans-unit.source: The following command demonstrates using the **more** function to page the output of Get-Command:
trans-unit.target: The following command demonstrates using the **more** function to page the output of Get-Command:

trans-unit.source: If you include one or more filenames as arguments to the more function, the function will read the specified files and page their contents to the host:
trans-unit.target: If you include one or more filenames as arguments to the more function, the function will read the specified files and page their contents to the host:

trans-unit.source: Discarding Output (Out-Null)
trans-unit.target: Discarding Output (Out-Null)

trans-unit.source: The **Out-Null** cmdlet is designed to immediately discard any input it receives.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-Null** cmdlet is designed to immediately discard any input it receives.

trans-unit.source: This is useful for discarding unnecessary data that you get as a side-effect of running a command.
trans-unit.target: This is useful for discarding unnecessary data that you get as a side-effect of running a command.

trans-unit.source: When type the following command, you do not get anything back from the command:
trans-unit.target: When type the following command, you do not get anything back from the command:

trans-unit.source: The **Out-Null** cmdlet does not discard error output.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-Null** cmdlet does not discard error output.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you enter the following command, a message is displayed informing you that Windows PowerShell does not recognize 'Is-NotACommand':
trans-unit.target: For example, if you enter the following command, a message is displayed informing you that Windows PowerShell does not recognize 'Is-NotACommand':

trans-unit.source: Printing Data (Out-Printer)
trans-unit.target: Printing Data (Out-Printer)

trans-unit.source: You can print data by using the **Out-Printer** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can print data by using the **Out-Printer** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The **Out-Printer** cmdlet will use your default printer if you do not provide a printer name.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-Printer** cmdlet will use your default printer if you do not provide a printer name.

trans-unit.source: You can use any Windows-based printer by specifying its display name.
trans-unit.target: You can use any Windows-based printer by specifying its display name.

trans-unit.source: There is no need for any kind of printer port mapping or even a real physical printer.
trans-unit.target: There is no need for any kind of printer port mapping or even a real physical printer.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have the Microsoft Office document imaging tools installed, you can send the data to an image file by typing:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have the Microsoft Office document imaging tools installed, you can send the data to an image file by typing:

trans-unit.source: Saving Data (Out-File)
trans-unit.target: Saving Data (Out-File)

trans-unit.source: You can send output to a file instead of the console window by using the **Out-File** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can send output to a file instead of the console window by using the **Out-File** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following command line sends a list of processes to the file **C:\\temp\\processlist.txt**:
trans-unit.target: The following command line sends a list of processes to the file **C:\\temp\\processlist.txt**:

trans-unit.source: The results of using the **Out-File** cmdlet may not be what you expect if you are used to traditional output redirection.
trans-unit.target: The results of using the **Out-File** cmdlet may not be what you expect if you are used to traditional output redirection.

trans-unit.source: To understand its behavior, you must be aware of the context in which the **Out-File** cmdlet operates.
trans-unit.target: To understand its behavior, you must be aware of the context in which the **Out-File** cmdlet operates.

trans-unit.source: By default, the **Out-File** cmdlet creates a Unicode file.
trans-unit.target: By default, the **Out-File** cmdlet creates a Unicode file.

trans-unit.source: This is the best default in the long run, but it means that tools that expect ASCII files will not work correctly with the default output format.
trans-unit.target: This is the best default in the long run, but it means that tools that expect ASCII files will not work correctly with the default output format.

trans-unit.source: You can change the default output format to ASCII by using the **Encoding** parameter:
trans-unit.target: You can change the default output format to ASCII by using the **Encoding** parameter:

trans-unit.source: **Out-file** formats file contents to look like console output.
trans-unit.target: **Out-file** formats file contents to look like console output.

trans-unit.source: This causes the output to be truncated just as it is in a console window in most circumstances.
trans-unit.target: This causes the output to be truncated just as it is in a console window in most circumstances.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you run the following command:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output will look like this:
trans-unit.target: The output will look like this:

trans-unit.source: To get output that does not force line wraps to match the screen width, you can use the **Width** parameter to specify line width.
trans-unit.target: To get output that does not force line wraps to match the screen width, you can use the **Width** parameter to specify line width.

trans-unit.source: Because **Width** is a 32-bit integer parameter, the maximum value it can have is 2147483647.
trans-unit.target: Because **Width** is a 32-bit integer parameter, the maximum value it can have is 2147483647.

trans-unit.source: Type the following to set the line width to this maximum value:
trans-unit.target: Type the following to set the line width to this maximum value:

trans-unit.source: The **Out-File** cmdlet is most useful when you want to save output as it would have displayed on the console.
trans-unit.target: The **Out-File** cmdlet is most useful when you want to save output as it would have displayed on the console.

trans-unit.source: For finer control over output format, you need more advanced tools.
trans-unit.target: For finer control over output format, you need more advanced tools.

trans-unit.source: We will look at those in the next chapter, along with some details about object manipulation.
trans-unit.target: We will look at those in the next chapter, along with some details about object manipulation.
